properties.Info: Bangor is one of the smallest cities in the UK and dates back to the early 6th century and the founding of a monastic establishment. The word �Bangor� is an old Welsh word for a type of fenced-in enclosure. The University, which swells the town with over 8,000 students, was established in 1884

Snowdonia is a spectacular National Park of some 838 square miles and the first to be created in Wales. The name comes from the mountain, which has been taken from the Saxon �Snow Dun�, meaning �snow hill�

Snowdon is the highest mountain in England and Wales at 1085 metres. It has also been described as the busiest mountain in the UK because of the number of people who climb it, as well as the thousands who go up by the steam train. In 2009 a new mountain top station and caf� replaced a rather ugly older one
Crib Goch is what is known as a knife-edge Ar�te, which is French for �fishbone�. At 923 metres it is a dangerous place for unwary climbers and there have been several fatalities over the years

properties.Loc: Bwlchysaethau (ridge over Lynn Glaslyn and Llydaw)
properties.Info: This is a high ridge running south from Snowdon and overlooking Llyn Glasyn and Llyn Llydaw

Links.title: Two Lynx navy helicopters out of Caernavon

properties.Loc: Snowdon Train on lower half of mountain
properties.Info: The railway is the only public rack and pinion one in the UK and has been in operation for more than a hundred years opening in 1896. The single track has passing loops along the way in order for trains to pass. The trains start from Llanberis and there are several halts and stations along the route.

Tryfan is most often climbed from the north, as it lies close to the A5 road and is a good starting point. For almost the whole route it is a scramble rather than a gentle climb. At the top are the Adam and Eve rocks, which from the ground seem to resemble two people

Links.title: Snowdon Train on lower half of mountain

properties.Info: The falls drop 37 metres into a small plunge pool, where it is possible to swim, though the water remains pretty cold throughout the year
Also known as Meini Hirion in Welsh and Druid�s Circle in English the stone circle is one of the finest in Wales. It has thirty stones, with ten still standing

This wonderful fantasy castle built in the 1820�s may at last have a future having lain derelict from the late 1980�s. A hotel chain bought the castle in 2006 and will hopefully bring it back to life, as a 90 room luxury hotel

Two historically important bridges cross the Menai Straits, the first is the Britannia road and rail bridge of 1850, which was largely re-built in the 1970�s following a fire, and the earlier suspension bridge of Thomas Telford from 1826, which was the first crossing over the straits

Because Beaumaris was never finished, or used, it ironically remains in a better condition that most other castles. This was the last fortress in Edward I�s Iron Ring, and building took place for thirty five years from 1295. The moat was filled by a tidal lock

Links.title: Bwlchysaethau (ridge over Lynn Glaslyn and Llydaw)

properties.Info: This is one of the great Norman revival mock castles of the early 19th century complete with a great keep. It is estimated that it may have cost around �150,000 to build, which in today�s money is close to 50 million pounds. It was built for the Pennant family, who had made a fortune from nearby Bethesda slate mining and Jamaican sugar

Overlooking the small town of Llanfairfechan is a quarry, which in the early 20th century employed over a thousand men, many of whom would have lived in the town. The extracted granite was exported not only to Liverpool but too many other major UK cities.

Links.title: Bwlchysaethau (ridge over Lynn Glaslyn and Llydaw)

properties.Info: Conwy Castle cost Edward I literally millions of pounds in modern money to build, probably close to a hundred and fifty. The style is linear due to the shape of the rocky promontory it sits on, and the walls extend right around the old town, as at Caernarfon. Three bridges cross the river including the wrought iron tubular railway one from 1849

This famous resort, known as the �Queen of Welsh Resorts�, still retains much of its 19th century charm and continues to attract thousands of holiday makers. The railway arrived in 1858, which increased its popularity, as did the pier, built in 1878. Many famous people have stayed here including Winston Churchill, Lloyd George and the 19th century German Chancellor Otto Bismarck

Links.title: Bwlchysaethau (ridge over Lynn Glaslyn and Llydaw)

properties.Loc: Two Lynx navy helicopters out of Caernavon
properties.Info: The Westland Lynx is a British multi-purpose military helicopter built in Yeovil and designed for battlefield utility, search and rescue and anti-submarine warfare. The helicopter became operational in 1977

This is reputed to be the largest slate quarry in the world, which began back in 1770. It is still working and send slates all over the world, though the workforce is somewhat reduced from the 2,000 people employed in the 19th century

Links.title: Two Lynx navy helicopters out of Caernavon

properties.Info: This is one of the few castles in north Wales, which was built in the early 13th century by Llywelyn ap Gruffydd, Prince of Wales. It was later captured by Edward I in 1283 and strengthened by adding a new tower, now in ruins. It returned to Welsh hands in 1404 when Owain Glyndwr took the castle and then largely destroyed it.

The unique village of Portmeirion was the brainchild of the architect Sir Clough Williams-Ellis and inspired by the Mediterranean, and perhaps the town of Portofino on the Amalfi Coast. It is also known as �The Village� from the Prisoner series filmed in the 1960�s with Patrick McGoohan

Links.title: Bwlchysaethau (ridge over Lynn Glaslyn and Llydaw)

properties.Info: Built by Edward I as part if his Iron Ring of castles Harlech has been subject to several assaults and sieges. The seven year siege, begun in 1468 during the Wars of the Roses, has been memorialised in the famous song �Men of Harlech�, and was the longest known siege in the history of Britain
Powis Castle has gradually been turned from a fortress into a house with a rare and beautiful terraced garden from the late 17th century, which has survived the 18th century fashion for landscaping.

These very rare farm buildings were built in the mid 19th century and based around the principles of Prince Albert�s farm in Windsor Great Park. It had its own gas works, water powered turbine and even a funicular railway to transport manure slurry to a storage tank. The circular buildings allowed carts to turn around

Links.title: Two Lynx navy helicopters out of Caernavon

properties.Info: Barmouth lies on the estuary of the River Mawddach and grew in size around shipbuilding, before becoming a holiday resort when the railway arrived in the 1860�s. This was partly due to the town being the closest resort to the West Midlands.

Links.title: Bwlchysaethau (ridge over Lynn Glaslyn and Llydaw)

properties.Info: This is a beautiful valley in the Cambrian Mountains to the east of Dolgellau

Aberdovey grew around shipbuilding until the arrival of the railway in the 1860�s could bring holidaymakers to the sandy beaches around the town. Today Aberdovey is still a popular place, and one of its claims to fame is that the first Outward Bound centre was opened here in 1941

The coastal village of Borth fronts a long sandy beach and is a popular place for caravans and camping. One spectacular sight can be seen at very low tides where the stumps of an ancient forest become visible. Radiocarbon dating puts the forest back 3,500 years

In 1872 the first university in Wales was established here and put the town on the map. Today 9,000 students swell the population to around 20,000 people. The town also has become a tourist centre both for the coast and the stunning landscape, which lies inland from this relatively isolated town
Ancient dried stone walls create patterns in the landscape that go back centuries.
Twenty turbines stand on a hill just outside the village of Trefenter, and have been here since 1993
Sited on a rocky promontory above the River Teifi Cilgerran Castle was built in the 13th century. From its high position it could attack with a catapult any invading ship coming up-river
The Preseli Mountains are now part of the Pembrokeshire Coast National Park. It was from here that the Bluestone is believed to have been cut and transported to Stonehenge to create the inner circle
